title: Futurism Typeface
content:
I'm struggling to find a font from the Futurism movement. Does anyone know any common typefaces from the 20th century that were used in futuristic works? (1909-1920s).

Also, I read somewhere that Studley is a font that was used. Does anyone know where I can download this, or if it is even available digitally?

I greatly appreciate any help you can give me.
author: stacems

comments.content:
Most obvious would be [P22 Futurismo](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042441/http:/www.p22.com/products/futurismo.html) ;-)

Although it's not really from that era, more inspired by...

And of course FuturA, which is used here:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042441im_/http:/typophile.com/files/futurist_cookbook_4444.gif)

If you're not a big fan of pieces of glass as an ingredient I wouldn't recommend it...

And there is the nifty MyFont search: [http://www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=1920s](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042441/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=1920s)

...and filter out the Art Deco fonts, although I've also seen those used. It's probably more about placement, suggesting movement:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042441im_/http:/typophile.com/files/marinetti_3967.gif)

( I'll stop doing your homework now ;-) )

Thanks for your input, although I suppose I should have mentioned that I've already found P22 Il Futurismo, and that I'm looking for more of a body text typeface.

I'm really hoping to find something that somehow is an integral part of the Futurism period. (Il Futurismo is of course, but is more of a display type, rather than a body text type.)

Also, Futura is more of a Bauhaus and Constructivism typeface.

I don't think there really is a typical futurist (body) typeface. From what I've seen (so far) they used typefaces that were at hand (like Bauhaus or Art Deco or plain) and played with composition.

But I'm not an expert on the matter. I didn't mean to state things you already know, I was just intriged by your question. It's an interesting movement.

Have you seen this book already?:  
 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/ad\_symphoniam/2399701501/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322042441/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/ad_symphoniam/2399701501/)

If you don't purchase it, I might ;-)

Don't worry about it. =) How could you know what I do and do not know. ;)

With my findings I have come to realize this too; that there is no specific font. I was hoping someone else could tell me different, but it seems everyone I ask comes to the same conclusion.

That book has come up in my searches, but I am unable to purchase anything at this time.

Thanks very much for your help.
